#Text=Prune
#Text=Limelight Hydrangeas
#Text=Limelight hydrangeas are a type of woody hydrangea that bloom in the spring .
#Text=They produce large flowers that are notorious for their football shape and their rich coloring .
#Text=Limelight hydrangeas are a beautiful addition to your yard or landscape , and if you have them , you might be wondering how to take care of them .

#Text=All you have to do is cut your hydrangea back when it is getting too big , remove all your dead flower heads , and thin out your plant , and you ’ll be pruning your limelight hydrangea like a professional .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Deciding When to Prune
#Text=Prune in late winter/early spring when your plant is winterized .
#Text=You can prune limelight hydrangeas at any time of the year , because they are hearty plants .
#Text=However , it is easiest to prune them in the late winter or early spring , because all of the leaves will have fallen off and you will be able to see and access the branches easily .
#Text=Cut your hydrangea when it is getting too big for your space .
#Text=You may have planted your hydrangea with a designated area in mind for it to grow .
#Text=Limelight hydrangeas can grow up to tall , so you might have to cut them back if they outgrow their space .
#Text=Hydrangeas are hearty plants , so cutting them back wo n’t hurt them .
#Text=In fact , it helps them grow bigger and faster .
#Text=Trim your hydrangea if the flowers make the branches droop .
#Text=Sometimes , limelight hydrangeas will produce so many flowers that their branches ca n’t hold all of the weight .
#Text=You might notice that your plant ’s branches are sagging , or the overall shape of the hydrangea is droopy .
#Text=This means you should probably thin it out .
#Text=Hydrangea flowers are usually fairly large , and they can hold on to a lot of water during the rainy season .
#Text=This makes them especially heavy .
#Text=Trimming Your Plant
#Text=Sanitize your pruners before starting .
#Text=When you cut parts of a plant , you are leaving it vulnerable to infection .
#Text=Clean your pruning tool with a mixture of water and soap in a bucket to quickly sanitize your tool .
#Text=You do n’t have to spend a lot of time on this step , but make sure your pruners are clean before you start cutting .
#Text=You can buy hand pruners at most hardware or home improvement stores .
#Text=Cut off all the old flower heads .
#Text=Your hydrangea will still have its old flowers on it from the previous year ’s bloom .
#Text=These flowers are dead , as you ’ll probably be able to tell by their color and dried out feel .
#Text=Start by cutting these flower heads off at their base .
#Text=Clip branches above nodes at an angle .
#Text=Look for the nodes on the branches of your hydrangea .
#Text=These will look like two small bumps next to each other .
#Text=The nodes are what create new growth .
#Text=Clip right above those so that they stay on your plant and make it easier for it to create new branches .
#Text=Always clip at an angle so that water does n’t pool on top of where you cut .
#Text=If the nodes are hard to see , use your fingers to feel for two pin-head sized bumps that are side by side .
#Text=Cut the hydrangea down to half its size to keep it small .
#Text=If you ’d like to stop your hydrangea from getting too big , you can cut it down to half of its size .
#Text=Limelight hydrangeas in particular are great at coming back from huge chops , and your plant will have no problem recovering from being cut down like this .
#Text=Do n’t cut your hydrangea shorter than above the ground .
#Text=Any shorter , and it might be too hard for your plant to grow back .
#Text=Cut off long branches to make it look uniform .
#Text=If you ’d like your plant to grow in a more uniform manner , you can cut off any long or straggling branches that are sticking out and making it look messy .
#Text=Simply cut them down to where they are even with the rest of the branches .
#Text=Pruning like this is entirely up to your stylistic discretion .
#Text=You can choose to shape your hydrangea however you ’d like .
#Text=Just remember that it will grow leaves and new flowers in the spring .
#Text=Remove smaller branches to declutter your plant .
#Text=If you want your plant to have flowers that are bigger , you can cut away any small branches from the base of your hydrangea .
#Text=This will send all of the plant ’s energy into the large branches when it is time to bloom , and give you big , beautiful flowers .
#Text=You can also leave the small branches in your plant to give it more flowers , but they will be smaller .
#Text=Try leaving the small branches in your hydrangea for a season and see how the flowers look .
#Text=If they are too small , you can cut them out in the winter .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Pruners
